newsitem.title: DUBAI: UAE official says Israeli market discouraging.
newsitem.headline: UAE official says Israeli market discouraging.

text.p: A United Arab Emirates official in remarks published on Saturday said the Israeli market had nothing to offer Gulf Arabs and that it would be difficult to overcome psychological barriers.

"There is a psychological barrier between the Gulf and Arab citizen and Israelis, and breaking it will not be easy...," Dubai Economic Department general director Mohammad al-Abbar told Al-Khaleej newspaper.
"From an economic viewpoint, the Gulf Arab private sector would not benefit from dealing with the Israeli market," he added.
He said interaction with Israel could only take place when comprehensive peace is reached in the Middle East.
Qatar and Oman have raced ahead of other Gulf Arab states is establishing economic ties with Israel but stopped short of diplomatic relations pending the resolution of all Arab-Israeli conflicts.

The six Gulf Arab states -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, UAE, Oman and Qatar -- say they will consider establishing diplomatic ties with Israel only when a just and comprehensive peace is reached, including on the Syrian and Lebanese tracks.
